content: The Act is titled the "Air Force Science and Technology for the 21st Century Act." It establishes the Office of Air Force Research. The "Air Force Science and Technology for the 21st Century Act" establishes the Office of Air Force Research, headed by a Director of Air Force Research who advises the Secretary and Chief of Staff of the Air Force on research matters and represents the Air Force on research issues with other agencies. The "Air Force Science and Technology for the 21st Century Act" establishes the Office of Air Force Research, headed by a Director of Air Force Research who advises the Secretary and Chief of Staff of the Air Force on research matters and represents the Air Force on research issues with other agencies. The Director of Air Force Research holds the grade of major general unless appointed to a higher grade under another provision of law. There is also a Deputy Director of Air Force Research in the Senior Executive Service responsible for the execution and operational aspects of the Air Force Research Laboratory. The Office of Air Force Research performs duties prescribed by the Secretary of the Air Force related to research promotion and planning. The Director of Air Force Research oversees Air Force research activities, including management of science and technology programs to advance research, development, test, and evaluation under the authority of the Secretary of the Air Force. The Office of Air Force Research coordinates Air Force research and reports to the Secretary. The Air Force Science and Technology Policy Council includes key officials to oversee research and development activities. The Air Force Science and Technology Policy Council, consisting of key officials, advises on policy, budget, and future technological capabilities for the Air Force. They oversee major science and technology programs to meet identified capabilities and determine the balance between meeting requirements and pursuing long-term technologies. The Air Force Science and Technology Policy Council advises on policy, budget, and future technological capabilities for the Air Force. They prioritize and endorse planning for the transition of science and technology to higher levels of research, development, test, and evaluation. The Council appoints a staff to assist in carrying out its responsibilities. Additionally, the Secretary of the Air Force may appoint an Air Force Scientific Advisory Board consisting of up to 15 civilians in the fields of science, research, and development work to consult and advise Air Force leadership. The Director of Air Force Research is exempt from certain employment laws in connection with any claim involving the United States. The Office of Air Force Research, Air Force Science and Technology Policy Council, and Air Force Scientific Advisory Board are established. The Director of Air Force Research is added as a new paragraph in Section 8014(b) of title 10, United States Code.
